awd_titl_txt: I/UCRC CGI: Collaborative Research - I/UCRC for Identification Technology Research
awd_abstract_narration:
The purpose of this proposal is to start a new I/UCRC "Identification Technology Research (CITeR)" with a focus on technologies of human measurement, identity, and intent that rest on firm pillars of trust, privacy, security, and reliability. The lead of the proposed Center will be Clarkson (CU) with site locations at the West Virginia University (WVU) and the University of Arizona (UA). 

Technologies to measure, monitor, identify humans and human intent are needed for a broad range of commercial and security applications. The use of technology to both improve performance (e.g. as minimizing false alarms for a given desired positive detection rate) or improving user interface (e.g. speeding lines through airports) will have a strong benefit to society. The proposed center will seek advanced theoretical and analytical techniques for developing algorithms and assessing performance of tools and systems that for human and intent identification. Such tools are needed for a variety of applications, and the current state of the art provides significant room for advancement. 

The proposed center builds upon the past success of an existing center that has been in operation since 2001. West Virginia University and University of Arizona have been the key players in CITeR since its inception, while others such as Michigan State have made notable contributions in areas such as image processing. In this proposal, Clarkson University as the lead institution adds complementary Center capabilities for measurements and signal processing to identity humans and human intent, and expands the center in an important way. 

The proposed research plan represents an appropriate set of projects for comprehensively addressing needs in this area. The investigators are well-qualified to carry out the research, and many have a significant, well-respected research track record in their fields. 

CITeR will focus on research, education, and technology dissemination. CITeR's leadership with Clarkson to develop the Diversity 2050 Initiative program is an active program to identify and address educational needs of next-generation professionals in the identification technology arena, and is likely to lead to a broad-reaching and positive impact to higher education in these areas. The proposal lays out a clear plan for engaging the other CiTER sites in this effort. The proposed and re-organized CITeR will extend its research core while building on the solid foundation of the past. The proposed program builds on an existing center that has had great success since its inception in 2001, with more than 80 projects that have involved 22 faculty and 130 students.

por.por_cntn:
During the past 5 years, the Center for the Management of Information (CMI) at the University of Arizona (UA) as a member of the Center for Identification Technology Research (CITeR) -- a National Science Foundation (NSF) Industry/University Cooperative Research Center (I/UCRC) has played a key role in advancing state of the art technology in deception detection by focusing on the theoretical foundations of credibility assessment and the systems that enable such assessments.  As the second site to join CITeR, UA was instrumental in helping to drive CITeR’s mission to advance identification technology and focus on the areas of biometric systems and credibility assessment.  UA’s portfolio of activities, during its tenure on this program, achieved mission goals through interdisciplinary research into emerging enabling technologies, cross training of scientists and engineers, and facilitation of technology transfer to the private and government sectors through its affiliates and collaborative partners.

Over this course of this program, CMI, through its research into the art and science of deception detection and credibility assessment, has redefined the way we evaluate individual’s motivations and intent.  CMI attributes much of this success due to its approach that places an emphases on observational and experimental research grounded in both data and theory. Data collected in the laboratory and in the field was analyzed using traditional statistical analysis and machine learning techniques to identify complex patterns and relationships.  These observational and experimental findings were used to develop systems and demonstrate theoretical validity.

During each year of the program, UA was required to report on key achievements of that years projects that included significant outcomes, these outcome included items such as publications and inventions, opportunities and training for students and researchers, and key project accomplishments.  UA results in these areas has been significant.  In the area publications, UA has produced more than 120 peer review publications that includes journal papers, conference papers, and book chapters.  Not included in this publication number are the numerous webinars, speaking appearance, and follow on proposals done by the research staff that were a result of the many research projects under this program.  This program has seen 12 PhD candidates graduate and has provided the opportunity for over 50 masters’ students and undergraduates to engage in meaningful research.  The benefits students received include but are not limited to:

  • experience with experimental data collection and preparation
  • exposure to research methods, tools, and analysis techniques
  • participation on dynamic and highly skilled research teams
  • mentoring and networking opportunities

The UA projects funded over the course of this program number in the dozens and specific details of those projects are available from the numerous publications resulting from those projects; however, one of our most recent project provides good example of the type of projects that UA tackled. 

The title of this project was: “Biometric-Enabled Interview-Assisting Traveller Screening (IATS) Technology for True Identity and Intention Recognition in Automated Border Control (ABC)”.  The researchers were: Burgoon, Gorodnichy, Nunamaker, Walls, Elkins & Golob.  Working with the Canadian Border Services Agency (CBSA) UA developed and implemented first AVATAR customs screening system (based on Declaration Card E311).  UA then designed and incorporated most-realistic drug smuggling experiment to-date using CBSA simulated contraband.  As part of this experimental design numerous improvements were made over prior experiments of this type, these improvements included:  Implemented faster eye tracking calibration phase, reduced eye calibration time by 70% and reducing passenger fatigue, and developed new CIT and interview protocol for identifying customs violations.  Using these improvements and experimental design a successful field test was conducted in Ottawa, Canada where we processed 70 mock passengers scanning their travel documents and recording their eyes, voice, and face behavior.  Subsequent behavioral data was used to automate risk assessment based on experimental ground truth and a results have been published.  A graphic showing the developed AVATAR system, the Canadian Team, and the UA Research Team is provided in Figure 1.

Moving forward beyond this program, CMI at UA will continue to increase knowledge in the area of credibility assessment by expanding our research to include:

  • New detection modalities
  • New detection sensors
  • Deep Learning Techniques
  • Data Fusion Algorithms

to solve meaningful real world problems.
